title: Utility & Internet Costs in Saint Helena
content:
The cost of utilities and internet in Saint Helena can vary, but on average, a monthly utility bill for an 85 sqm apartment can range from $150 to $300 USD, while internet plans with 60 Mbps speed can cost around $50 to $100 USD per month.

[FACTBOX]

Internet (60 Mbps): ($75 USD/month)
Mobile Data (10GB): ($30 USD/month)
Electricity Cost: ($0.35 per kWh)
Currency: SHP
[/FACTBOX]

[SECTION] Utility Costs Overview [/SECTION]
The utility infrastructure in Saint Helena is relatively well-developed, with a reliable supply of electricity, water, and garbage collection services. However, the costs of these utilities can fluctuate due to seasonal variation, with higher demand during the peak tourist season from June to September. The Saint Helena Government regulates the utility prices, and any changes are typically announced in advance to allow residents to adjust their budgets. The cost of utilities can also vary depending on the location, with apartments in Jamestown tend to be more expensive than those in rural areas.

The quality of utility services in Saint Helena is generally good, with a high level of customer satisfaction. However, there may be occasional disruptions to services due to maintenance or extreme weather conditions. Residents are advised to check with their utility providers for any planned outages or interruptions. The government is also investing in renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power, to reduce the island's reliance on fossil fuels and lower the cost of electricity.

[SECTION] Utility Tips [/SECTION]
- To set up utilities, residents should contact the relevant providers, such as Sure or Cable & Wireless, and provide proof of address and identification.
- Prepaid electricity meters are available, but postpaid plans may offer more flexibility and better rates for heavy users.
- The best internet providers in Saint Helena are Sure and Cable & Wireless, offering a range of plans and bundles.
- To save on utility bills, residents can consider using energy-efficient appliances, turning off lights and electronics when not in use, and using public transport or walking instead of driving.
- Residents can also take advantage of government initiatives, such as the **Renewable Energy Scheme**, which offers discounts and incentives for households that install solar panels or wind turbines.
